review.title: Causal Graph Justifications of Logic Programs
review.abstract: In this work we propose a multi-valued extension of logic programs under the stable models semantics where each true atom in a model is associated with a set of justifications. These justifications are expressed in terms of causal graphs formed by rule labels and edges that represent their application ordering. For positive programs, we show that the causal justifications obtained for a given atom have a direct correspon- dence to (relevant) syntactic proofs of that atom using the program rules involved in the graphs. The most interesting contribution is that this causal information is obtained in a purely semantic way, by algebraic op- erations (product, sum and application) on a lattice of causal values whose ordering relation expresses when a justification is stronger than another. Finally, for programs with negation, we define the concept of causal stable model by introducing an analogous transformation to Gelfond and Lifschitz's program reduct. sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: An important difference between the classical models and most logical programming (LP) semantics is that, in the latter case, true atoms are able to be substantiated or justified by a certain derivative. Consequently, falsehood is ultimately understood as a lack of evidence: for example, a common informal way in which the actual requirement literally does not include p, "there is no way to derive p." Although this idea seems quite intuitive, it does in fact fall back on a concept of ways to derive p, outside the scope of standard LP semantics. In other words, LP semantics indicates whether there is any derivative for an atom, it does not provide the derivatives themselves if several alternatives exist. sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we have provided a multi-value semantics for normal logic programs, whose truth values form a grid of causal graphs. A causal graph is nothing more than a graph of rule applications that reflects a certain order of rule applications. Thus, a model assigns a value to each true atom that contains justifications for its derivation from the existing rules. We have also provided three basic grid operations: an addendum that stands for alternative, independent justifications; a product that represents a common interaction of causes; and a concatenation that reflects the application of rules. We have shown that for positive programs there is a minimal model that corresponds to the least fixed point of a direct consequence operator, analogous to van Emden and Kowalski (1976). Thus, we are able to transfer a direct correspondence between the semantic values we receive and the syntactic idea of proofs, which are interpreted by more stable models as the cause. "
